Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Cloud apps for animals: cutting costs and improving welfare
Award.AbstractNarration:
Work with animals is very valuable for society. Animals as pets provide companionship and well documented health benefits. Zoos and aquariums are often public cultural institutions, and licensed animal exhibitors can be found in all the major cities in the United States. Research on drugs, behavior, and development require the use of live animals. For example, by law a drug cannot be brought to market without testing on live animals. For each of these valuable ways animals help us, there is a heavy workload of animal care and data collection. When the workload cannot be met, animals from home pets to zoo favorites suffer from a lower quality of life, and the value of what we get from animals is reduced. Heavy workloads lead to poor data, fewer pets, and sad looking zoo animals. The proposed project focuses on a system, similar to a video game system, that allows for automation of animal-related activities. This proposed system can give animals physical toys and puzzles to keep them busy, provide fun challenges for them to solve, and reward them for physical exercise all of which help keep the animals physically and mentally healthy. It will also provide new ways for people to bond with their pets, automatically conduct experiments, and record data.

The goal of this I-Corps project is to identify the market need for devices which can improve animal welfare and automate data collection. This team will extensively interview in three potential market areas: pet owners, research laboratory decision makers, and zoo & aquarium staff. As the team members explore the market need, they will tailor their prototype system to meet market needs. The team will utilize the Schubot Exotic Bird Health Center at Texas A&M University to field test and scientifically validate the prototypes, then revisit their market areas with a product demonstration. If successful, they will develop a low cost, simple to use system that will allow animal caretakers, exhibitors, and researchers to automate much of their animal research and husbandry tasks. In this way the team will allow 1) pet owners to keep their animals busy and happy when they are away and to derive more benefits from pet ownership, 2) researchers to more efficiently and economically provide enrichment and run experiments, and 3) zookeepers to develop new interactive displays and provide highly stimulating activities for their animals. The team envisions the new device will work in the following way: load a game file, fill the object dispenser, and walk away knowing the system will exercise, entertain, feed, teach, research, or medicate the animal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This I-Corps project successfully advanced product development to help get research laboratory technology to the public to help improve animal health and welfare. One graduate student and four undergraduate students learned how to do the research and development that precedes the production of a sound commercial product. Through this, this I-Corps grant is helping create future U.S. business leaders. The students involved were diverse, identifying as Afro-Latino, West Indian, White, and both male and female. This is important because U.S. leadership in Translational Science depends on bringing together our entire diverse population. We need "all hands on deck" to maintain leadership at a global level.

During the intensive I-Corps training, we learned a wide array of business techniques that are beginning to help our home department. We are now using the "lean start up" business development techniques in developing projects and funding requests. This is helping us reduce waste of effort and maximizes the impact of spending. The "minimum viable product" concept is also allowing us to better focus our development research. Treating science more like a business has been beneficial to us and to our wider departmental community.

The I-Corp process also helped us connect to a strong customer base, allowing us to make each step of our work relevant to the general public while still meeting our science goals. Having this group of potential customers to cheerlead and critique helps ground our work and focus on outcomes that can apply outside the laboratory.The partners we met through I-Corps are clamoring to use the technology at their facilities to improve animal welfare for pets and zoo animals, both building our customer base and creating partnerships for further product development.

In terms of scientific products, while supported by the I-Corp processes, we produced a scientific study with strong preliminary results. We were able to automate stress reduction in animals through the use of a “video game.” Animals that received the game showed a 98% drop in stress-associated behaviors compared to controls. This study of 12 birds was used as a basis for a successful grant for a larger scale experiment using customer owned animals. This larger scale study, funded by the Texas A&M Veterinary School, will begin next month. One of the I-Corps students, who is now a Veterinary professional student, will be leading the project. It will test techniques to reduce stress and fear of people among privately owned animals. Thanks to I-Corps, she learned about R&D and is now bringing product development and research into her professional development beyond undergraduate learning.

The graduate student who was the Entrepreneurial Lead of the I-Corps team is now focusing on this technology development for her PhD dissertation. The I-Corps team applied for and was awarded a National Science Foundation AIR-TT award, which has created a large student lead team that is now developing commercial products and learning about fundraising and business building in partnership with scientific development. During I-Corps we began the early stages of automated exercise "games" designed to keep animals healthy through increased exercise.

Thanks to the work funded by I-Corps, research techniques are being introduced into private industry, a Veterinary School is learning about product development, better ties are being made between the public and researchers through hundreds of potential customers, a new scientific research tool for measuring animal behavior is being developed, and products to improve animals' well-being are being created for wide commercial distribution.


 


Last Modified: 04/26/2018
Modified by: Donald Brightsmith

    Tim Stephenson

    Constance Woodman

    Donald Brightsmith
    Bonding time with a parakeet
  • Daniel Carey demonstrates how the software can interact with birds by using a puppet. made by the research team, the puppet allowed for testing many small software changes without bothing the research parrots.
    Constance Woodman
    Creative Commons
    Donald Brightsmith
    Engineer uses a bird puppet to test software.
